I fear dynamic mock objects, but like many fears, it may be because I
haven't used them.

I have some readability concerns, but the big issue I had was the list
approach to specifying return data (return this on the first call, this
on the second call, etc).  In my JDBC and HTTP tests, this has made a
few tests kind of brittle when the order or number of calls to an
accessor method has changed.   The code still works, it also still
conforms to the expectations of the interface, it just does things a
little differently.

Have you had these issues as well, and are there workarounds?  In my
mock objects that I write by hand, I'm often either returning one thing
all the time, or I implement a map for look-ups:

public String getMiddleName(Person person) {
    return (String)middleNameData.get(person);
}

-Kevin Klinemeier

--- Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...> wrote:

> You could have used dynamic mocks (a la 
>
http://mockobjects.sourceforge.net/javadoc/1.4/com/mockobjects/dynamic/Mock.html
> 
> or http://mockobjects.com/DynaMock.html) wherein you tell your mock
> what 
> calls, results, and constraints are expected.  Then you just send the
> message 
> verify() to the mock at the end of the test.
